title: State budget swings to P2.2-B surplus in Jan
text:
State budget swings to P2.2-B surplus in Jan By Mary Grace Padin   
MANILA, Philippines - The government posted a budget surplus of P2.2 billion in January as growth in revenue collection outpaced spending, the Bureau of the Treasury (BTr) reported yesterday. 
Data from the BTr showed the government’s fiscal balance reached the positive scale with P2.2 billion in surplus in January 2017, a reversal from the P3.47 billion in deficit recorded in the same month last year. 
The last time the government recorded a budget surplus was in August 2016. 
“This reflects improved revenue collection effort and prudent spending with year-on-year growth of 10 percent and seven percent for revenues and expenditures, respectively,” the BTr said. 
Government revenue during the period rose by almost 10 percent to P200.3 billion from the P182.23 billion posted the same month in 2016. The bulk, or 92 percent of government revenue came from tax collections. 
The government’s largest revenue collecting arm, the Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR), collected P147.4 billion in January, 14 percent up from P129.65 billion in the same period last year.   
The increase was attributed to higher taxpayer compliance, as well as the reforms implemented by the BIR, such as the expansion of its Large Taxpayers Service. 
Earlier, Internal Revenue Commissioner Caesar Dulay committed to expand its list of large taxpayers from 2,320 to 3,000 to improve the bureau’s tax collection effort. 
Likewise, the Bureau of Customs (BOC) also registered a 16-percent growth in its collections in January 2017. The Bureau collected P35.9 billion as compared to P31.08 billion in the same month in 2016. 
“Same with BIR, the BOC had implemented sweeping reforms to improve their collections for this year,” the BTr said. 
Non-tax revenues, on the other hand, decreased 21 percent to P15.97 billion from P20.33 billion last year. 
The decreased was slightly cushioned by the BTr’s income, which inched up by one percent to P8 billion due to higher interest on the advances to government-owned and -operated corporations, as well as improvement in the income of the Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corp. 
“These compensated for the lower interest income earned on national deposits lodged with the BSP (Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas),” the BTr said. 
Meanwhile, the national government’s spending in January 2017 also improved by seven percent to P198.1 billion as compared to P185.7 billion in the same period last year.
